name: Herb Aust
title: Partner & Operations Manager
location: Scottsdale, AZ is already on the list. Let me provide the next best option:\n\nMaui, HI

flow.context: Herb Aust is Partner & Operations Manager at Maui Lodging Properties, a family-run vacation rental company in Lahaina, Maui — he runs day-to-day ops, maintenance coordination, and guest services, and his personal cell is literally the published emergency contact number. Company uses Escapia for bookings, does monthly full-property inspections with detailed reports, but has no detected ops or photo platform like Breezeway — about 25 staff, founded 2010 by Darlene Ford who now oversees things remotely from Oregon. Bill 9 is creating serious regulatory pressure in Maui, phasing out thousands of STRs by 2029. Strongest connection: Herb went to Indiana University of Pennsylvania for Business Management — Sam is at Carnegie Mellon in Pittsburgh, fellow PA people.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Herb — kinda random, but I'm at Carnegie Mellon out in Pittsburgh right now and saw you went to IUP. Fellow Pennsylvania guy. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye — have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Smile. Relaxed energy. Don't rush the PA connection — let it land. If he reacts to the PA thing, roll with it for a beat before moving on.

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone on the ops side like you. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let them talk. Whatever they say, use it as a bridge into discovery. Don't correct anything they got wrong.

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I work with a few other vacation rental operators and your name came up because you run the ops side at Maui Lodging. Mind if I take 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out?
heard_no.note: Self-deprecating joke, then quick transition. Don't linger on the joke.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? What day works better?
bad_timing.note: Don't apologize. Offer a specific window, not an open-ended 'when works for you.'

reschedule_lock.label: LOCK CALLBACK
reschedule_lock.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. I'll keep it real quick. Thanks Herb, talk soon.
reschedule_lock.note: Calendar it immediately after hanging up. Set a reminder 5 minutes before. Note the Hawaii time zone.

confused_guarded.label: GUARDED — PERMISSION ASK
confused_guarded.say: Yeah totally fair — it is a cold call, I'll own that. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? You can totally hang up on me if it's not relevant.
confused_guarded.note: Owning the cold call disarms people fast. Stay calm, don't speed up, don't get defensive.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally on me. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that I caught you at a terrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: Diagnostic, not persuasive. You're splitting the objection into bad timing vs. genuine no. Listen for which one they pick.

branches.label: Curious now — what do you do?

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So here's why I called — I work with another ops manager at a vacation rental company pretty similar to yours. Maybe twenty-five, thirty properties. And the thing he kept telling me was, look, they've got inspections, they've got checklists, the cleaners take photos after every turnover — but nobody actually has time to sit there and go through every photo from every unit. So stuff slips through. Guest checks in, there's a stain on the couch or a missing remote, and now he's the one getting the call at nine o'clock at night because his number's the emergency line. Does any of that sound familiar?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after 'sound familiar.' Most important silence of the call. Herb's personal cell IS the published emergency number — this should hit close to home. Let the silence do the work.

branches.label: We already have a process for that
Not really our problem / Not interested

pain_resonates.label: PAIN RESONATES — DISCOVERY
pain_resonates.say: Yeah, I figured that'd hit close to home. So tell me — what does your inspection process actually look like right now? Like after a cleaner finishes a turnover, what happens next?
pain_resonates.note: STOP PITCHING. They're warm. Ask questions and listen. You want to learn: Do cleaners take photos? Who reviews them? What tool? What falls through cracks? Take notes.

branches.label: Shares a specific frustration or story

pain_lukewarm.label: LUKEWARM — QUICK SOLUTION + CTA
pain_lukewarm.say: Totally get it. The short version is we built something that looks at the photos your team's already taking during turnovers and automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues — no workflow change, no new app for your cleaners. We just plug into what you're already doing. Would you be open to taking a quick look sometime when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
pain_lukewarm.note: Don't force the pain harder — they're not biting on emotion, so go straight to a compact solution plus a soft CTA. If they bite, great.

discovery_tools.label: DISCOVERY — TOOLS
discovery_tools.say: Got it. And are your guys logging that stuff in Escapia, or do you have something separate for the inspection side — like a Breezeway or anything like that?
discovery_tools.note: We know they use Escapia for bookings. No Breezeway detected. If they have no dedicated inspection tool — huge opening. If they name something, ask what's working and what's not.

discovery_volume.label: DISCOVERY — VOLUME
discovery_volume.say: Makes sense. How many turnovers are you guys doing in a typical week? I'm just trying to get a sense of the photo volume your team's dealing with.
discovery_volume.note: More turnovers = more photos = more stuff missed = stronger case. This also sets up 'imagine AI reviewing all of those automatically.'

bill9_angle.label: BILL 9 — REGULATORY PRESSURE
bill9_angle.say: And I gotta ask — with Bill 9 coming down and all the uncertainty around the vacation rental phaseout, how's that affecting how you guys think about ops? I imagine every unit you've still got, you want airtight records on.
bill9_angle.note: Bill 9 phases out ~6,200 Maui STRs. West Maui deadline is Jan 2029. Fewer units = each one matters more. Airtight inspection records help with disputes and regulatory defense.

solution_drop.label: SOLUTION DROP + CTA
solution_drop.say: So here's the quick version — we built an AI layer that plugs into the photos your team's already taking and automatically catches damage, missing items, staging issues, anything that's off. No new workflow, no new app. It just reviews everything your team doesn't have time to look at. If nothing else, I could show you what a few other PM companies are doing with their turnover photos — worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would you be open to a quick look?
solution_drop.note: One breath on the solution, then CTA. The 'steal some ideas' line lowers the stakes. Then STOP TALKING. Let silence do the work.

meeting_yes.label: THEY'RE INTERESTED
meeting_yes.say: Awesome — I appreciate that. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday open. What works better on your end? I'll keep it tight, twenty minutes tops.
meeting_yes.note: Offer two specific days. Hawaii is 2-3 hours behind Pacific, 5-6 behind Eastern — plan accordingly. Don't leave scheduling open-ended.

branches.label: Needs to check calendar / Send me an invite

book_meeting.label: BOOK IT — LOCK IN
book_meeting.say: Perfect — I'll send a calendar invite right now. What's the best email for you? I've got the info-at-mauilodging one — do you have a direct address?
book_meeting.note: Get direct email. Email patterns suggest aust@mauilodging.com or herb@mauilodging.com. Once booked, STOP SELLING. Don't add one more thing.

end_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED — WRAP
end_booked.say: Sending it now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Herb — looking forward to it. Talk soon.
end_booked.note: Shut up and hang up. Send the invite within 60 seconds of hanging up.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. Quick question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox?
send_email.note: This keeps the conversation alive and gives you intel for a tailored email. Whatever they say, use it.

email_wrapup.label: EMAIL FOLLOW-UP — PLANT A TIME
email_wrapup.say: Got it — I'll put something together around that and keep it short. Would sometime next week work to hop on a quick call after you've had a chance to look at it? Maybe Tuesday or Wednesday?
email_wrapup.note: Plant a specific follow-up window. Send the email within the hour. Include a relevant example for their size and market. Put the follow-up time in the email too.

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool than to buy something new, especially with everything going on in the Maui market right now.
objection_no_budget.note: AGREE first. Don't push back. Pause a beat, then move to the split.

budget_split.label: BUDGET — SPLIT
budget_split.say: Just so nobody from my team cold calls you about this again — is it that budget this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything you try to buy right now puts you through the ringer with the partners?
budget_split.note: Darlene Ford (founder) oversees from Oregon and is still involved daily. If approval chain is the issue, offer to loop her in or make her life easier. If budget is truly locked, sell the test drive.

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally respect that. You're probably not buying anything this second, and that's fine. But the folks who move fastest when budget does open up are the ones who already know what's on their shortlist. Would you be open to just taking a look — not a commitment, just so it's on your radar? Twenty minutes, and if it's not a fit we part as friends.
sell_test_drive.note: Reframe the meeting as low-risk, future-oriented. You're not asking them to buy — you're asking them to be informed.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would've reached out to us, right?
objection_not_interested.note: AGREE. Surprise them by not pushing. Pause, then split the objection.

interest_split.label: NOT INTERESTED — SPLIT
interest_split.say: Just so I'm not bugging you — is it that this genuinely isn't a problem you're dealing with, or is it more that you hate cold calls and I caught you at the wrong time?
interest_split.note: Most people will admit they hate cold calls, which opens the door back up. If it's genuinely not their problem, pivot to a referral.

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with the number of properties you guys manage, you'd have to have something in place. I'd be surprised if you didn't.
objection_have_process.note: Validate them. Don't trash their process. Pause a beat, then split to find the gap.

process_split.label: PROCESS — SPLIT
process_split.say: Is it that you're totally covered and happy with how everything's working, or is it more that switching anything right now would just be a headache on top of everything else?
process_split.note: If they say 'happy' — compliment them and ask what's working (they'll naturally reveal gaps). If switching is the headache — emphasize zero workflow change, plugs into what they already do.

process_happy.label: PROCESS HAPPY — FIND THE GAP
process_happy.say: Love that — honestly most people I talk to don't have it fully dialed in, so that's impressive. Out of curiosity, what's working best for you guys? I'm always trying to learn what the good operators are doing.
process_happy.note: Flattery plus genuine curiosity. When people explain what works, they naturally reveal what doesn't. Listen for the gap. If they mention the monthly inspections or detailed reports, ask how many hours those take.

referral_not_me.label: NOT THE RIGHT PERSON — REFERRAL
referral_not_me.say: Totally hear you. Out of curiosity — who on your team typically owns the inspection workflow day-to-day? Or would something like this need to go through Bree or one of the other partners?
referral_not_me.note: We know Bree Lewis handles new clients and digital platforms — she's the next best path. Darlene Ford is the founder but remote in Oregon. Name-drop Bree naturally to signal you've done homework.

referral_get_name.label: GET THE REFERRAL
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — would you mind pointing me to the best way to reach them? If I can get a direct line or email, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands instead of being another random cold pitch.
referral_get_name.note: If Bree: her emergency number is 808-868-6558. If Darlene: she's remote in Oregon, no direct number found. Ask if you can mention Herb's name when reaching out.

branches.label: Says to just call the office

referral_confirm.label: CONFIRM REFERRAL — USE HERB'S NAME
referral_confirm.say: Appreciate that. And would it be cool if I mention your name when I reach out — just so they know it's not totally out of nowhere?
referral_confirm.note: Even a soft yes here turns your next call from cold to warm. Thank Herb genuinely regardless of the answer.

voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL
voicemail.say: Hey Herb — it's Sam Parks. I'm at Carnegie Mellon out in Pittsburgh, fellow PA guy. I work with a few vacation rental operators on their inspection workflows and wanted to run something quick by you. Shoot me a text or call back when you get a sec — it's [YOUR NUMBER]. Thanks man.
voicemail.note: Under 20 seconds. Sound casual, not rehearsed. The PA hook and 'inspection workflows' give him just enough to be curious. Follow up with a text right after: 'Hey Herb, Sam Parks here — just left you a VM. Work with a few VR operators on their turnover inspections. Worth a quick chat?'

end_graceful.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand, Herb. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time. Take care.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Stay warm. You may circle back in 3-4 weeks. Log the outcome and any intel in CRM immediately.
